column10: With newer APIs, there's often very little information. In addition, Swift (the language I predominantly work in) changes quickly, so sometimes information provided is already out of date.
column11: The "reputation" of the poster, the amount of technical detail, code samples, brevity.
column15: Most of the APIs I work with are provided by the platform vendor (Apple). As a result, generally if the API does what I want, I choose it. If not, I don't have a lot of other options.
column16: I'll usually open a new browser window and then fill it with tabs containing search results of my question. Then I can read through them all and synthesize a  solution.

column10: Stack Overflow is for specific questions and not the ideal place to find global opinions on a framework. But looking at several questions in a particular tag will help give a feeling for the library and sometimes its community too.
column11: Details and specific examples are always helpful (versus just hubris and blanket statements). When the tone is fair and balanced instead of harsh and absolute it lends the writer more credibility.
column15: Features, ease of use, documentation, size and culture of community, bugs, quality of implementation, performance, how well I understand its purpose, whether it's a do-all framework or a targeted library, ...

column17: Might help give a quick idea of what other developers think about different comparable libraries (e.g. web frameworks for the same stack). A short paragraph and popularity/star rating could help. GitHub offers pretty much this, just not in a single list and less discoverable.
column18: It can be easy to quickly dismiss something because of quick negative critical reactions (even if true, perhaps it's still better than something else overall). This is not specific to library/framework selection and must be guarded against by the consumer's self-awareness.

column8: I like to see how other developers have adopted a piece of API. They often have insights about particular trouble points, or have chosen one of several alternatives and can speak to the benefits of their choice.
column9: Almost universally with the site's search function.
column10: Many responses are only minimally informed, have made errors in their code samples, or directly contradict first-party documentation.
column11: Often, I have some sense of the API already, and am looking for more detail. I can gauge the quality of an opinion based on how much of the author's answer aligns with the facts I already know.
column15: My primary goal is to find the API that solves the problem I have correctly, even if it is more complex than other similar "convenience" APIs. A secondary goal is ease of use and fluency of the resulting code: while I'd like to arrive at a correct solution, I also want future developers to follow the code with a minimum of hassle.
column16: I'm not sure what this question is asking. Do you want me to list all the ways in which English communication can be aggregated? There are quite a few of them.
column17: I'm not sure what this question is asking. If summarization is beneficial to understanding API, then any problem even remotely related to that use stands to achieve a network benefit.
column18: I'm not sure what this question is asking. If summarization is detrimental to understanding API, then any problem even remotely related to that use stands to suffer a network loss.

column10: Finding the right search keywords. If I'm inexperienced or lacking information in a particular area, I may not be using the right terminology to hit the answers I'm looking for.
column11: Recency: posts more than a few years old are likely to be out of date and possibly counterproductive. Corroboration across multiple sources of information: rather than taking a single post in isolation, check across several to get a broader impression.
column15: Functionality: can it do the job I need it to? Productivity: how much of my time will it take, and will I enjoy it?
column16: I'm not sure I've seen an effective summary at this level. Information is typically very detailed and diverse (individual Stack Overflow posts), or too high-level (Wikipedia page, vendor web site).
column17: Getting a quick intro to an unfamiliar topic. Help with evaluating multiple APIs and choosing between them.
column18: Possibility of out-of-date information. When reviews are opinion-based, the potential for bias or manipulation in the results.

column8: Often important information about practical API usage isn't in official documentation and reading others' opinions is the quickest way to find it.
column9: I quickly skim posts to look for answers that appear credible and intelligently written, searching in different places if I didn't find any. There are usually very few.
column10: It works well. I have few complaints.
column11: It's easy to read a few lines of technical commentary and identify immediately whether the writer is a precise thinker who has an opinion worth reading.
column15: It's impossible to answer this generally.
column16: I don't think any kind of summarization is important. Contributors are already summarizing their opinions as best as possible.
